Guess I misunderstood what you're after @rehmetjan

we run a classifieds website on django+geodjango for a part of eastern Europe. The reason it's not been released as opensource is because we feel most of the code in there is specific to the way we wanted it to work and not too many people will find it useful without heavily modifying it. And designing it to be easily configurable would have been far more trouble than worth especially performance-wise. Plus we don't have the rights to the UI design. If you're interested in developing an OSS solution let me know what exactly you have in mind maybe I can help with it - we can certainly flesh out a lot of code out of what we have now.

Even a high-level description of your design could be useful. Don't give any details that your employers could reasonably regard as theirs without written permission. Same goes, of course, for the UI design.

... we use solr alot in our setup and a lot of parts of the projects are coupled to our custom code that talks to solr. But I think in a more general reusable project haystack would be a better option.

@holdenweb we - the company which I own. I'm not offering anything that can get me in trouble :). By not owning the UI design I mean it's been bought from an outsider and we don't own the rights to redistribute it in an OSS project.

It has 2 levels of categories. You can post classifieds in any second level cateogory. For each category there are rules defined. And each has possible purposes: sell, buy, rent or in a lost/found category lost, found etc. For each combination of these you have different validation rules for the form like if I want to sell something in the houses category I can enter price, images point on a map etc. If I want to buy a house there's no point so these fields are not allowed. You post each ad for a given region, validations were you can enter a point on map apply here as regions are defined with a polygon in the admin etc.

... the rules for each category/purpose are defined in the admin. The right form/validation is picked up at runtime. Dunno if this sounds like something that can have value in an OSS project we can help develop it.
